author: @english_mathrubhumi
title: Air India to discontinue Kochi-London flight service from March 30 onwards
text:
Representational Image | Arranged
Kochi: In a major blow to travelers, Air India has announced suspension of its Kochi-London service as part of major changes on its London flight schedule for the Northern Summer 2025 (NS25) season.
Kochi-London service will be suspended after March 30, 2025, removing the direct connectivity between Kerala and the UK. Currently, Air India operates flights on the route three times a week.
In September 2024, Cochin International Airport Limited (CIAL) launched the direct flight to London as part of a special Onam initiative. To encourage direct flights to Europe, CIAL waived parking and landing charges.
Air travel between India and the UK became smoother recently when the UK moved India from its red list to amber. Following this, CIAL, Air India, and the Government of Kerala worked together to establish the direct service from Kochi to Europe. Kochi is currently the only airport in Kerala with direct flights to Europe.
Subscribe to our Newsletter

author: Merry
title: Naomi Watts shares her grief after the death of her beloved grandmother three weeks after a stroke
text:
By Stephen Bisset for Daily Mail Australia
Published: 00:43 EDT, August 30, 2024 | Updated: 00:43 EDT, August 30, 2024
Naomi Watts has shared her grief following the death of her beloved grandmother at the age of 99.
The 55-year-old Australian-British actress took to Instagram on Friday to share the sad news that her “nanna” Nikki Roberts had passed away, three weeks after suffering a stroke.
Naomi shared a carousel of sweet snaps of herself with Nikki and their family members and paid tribute to her “down-to-earth” grandmother in a lengthy tribute.
She recounted how her grandmother had lived to her 99th birthday after suffering a stroke, achieving her goal of having one last party with all her relatives.
Sharing a photograph showing four generations of her family, Naomi praised her grandmother’s enduring legacy and admitted it is an emotional time for her family.
“My dear Nanna has left this world, but her spirit will never leave us,” the Mulholland Drive star began the touching post.
“I feel truly blessed to have had the most wonderful relationship with her. She is such a big part of who I am – her core values, her work ethic, her mischievous humor and her joy for life.”
“My mother and aunts are devastated today, but we know what a great life he had,” Naomi continued.
Naomi Watts shared her grief following the death of her beloved grandmother at the age of 99
The 55-year-old Australian-British actress took to Instagram on Friday to share the sad news that her “nanna” Nikki Roberts had passed away, three weeks after suffering a stroke.
“She kept going because she loved her life and her family. She lived three more weeks after a massive stroke because, at her wildest, she showed us that when she was finally ready to ‘hit it,’ she would hit it.”
“She had one more goal to accomplish: her 99th birthday! One more party, one more family reunion.”
To end the emotional post, Naomi praised Nikki for her humor and “no-nonsense attitude.”
“I will never forget his evil laugh, his fighting spirit, his no-nonsense attitude, his no-waste policy,” he exclaimed.
‘I was removing mould from bread and cheese: ‘You don’t need an expiry date, that’s what your nose is for! May their stories and memories live on.’
Naomi shared a carousel of sweet snaps of herself with Nikki and their family members and paid tribute to her “down-to-earth” grandmother in a lengthy tribute.
She recounted how her grandmother had lived to her 99th birthday after suffering a stroke, achieving her goal of having one last party with all her family members.
The post was met with an outpouring of support as her famous friends and fans sent their condolences.
Magnolia star Julianne Moore was quick to comment on the emotional post: “I’m so sorry for your loss. What a wonderful person.”
Silver screen icon Glenn Close also chimed in with a sweet sentiment.
“She laughs with the angels,” he wrote. “How lucky your family is to have had her.”
Pulp Fiction star Rosanna Arquette sent her heartfelt condolences, writing: ‘I am so sorry for your loss. You are blessed to have had her as a guide in your life and as an inspiration.’
Selma Blair also commented: “I am so sorry for your loss. May your memory be a blessing.”
Her Australian friends Rebecca Gibney, Natalie Imbruglia and Teresa Palmer also offered their thoughts as they supported Naomi.

author: @MelissaW0206
title: Concerns arise concerning the future of six captives in Gaza, following the Israeli Defense Forces' discovery of gunshot injuries.
text: Concerns escalate regarding the situation of six captives in Gaza, following the discovery of gunshot injuries by the Israeli Defense Forces. The unfortunate event has sparked concerns that more Israeli captives might not return alive, mentioned one demonstrator. "We need to bring back those we know were still alive," Daniel shared with CNN. He expressed that continuing the conflict while negotiations for a truce and hostage swap falter will only lead to more funerals, both for them and us, he added, aging 48. No formal explanation has been provided on how the six perished. IDF declared on Thursday that initial examinations indicate that all six captives had been fired upon, but the exact cause of their demise has yet to be determined. It also pointed out that the findings are provisional. IDF reported discovering four additional deceased individuals near the bodies of the six captives, believed to be Hamas militants who had been holding the captives. However, no signs of bullets were found on their bodies. IDF didn't assign any culprit. Outside Israel's Ministry of Defense, Daniel highlighted that IDF's announcement suggesting all six captives were shot underscores the threats involved in force-based rescue operations. On Tuesday, Israeli outlet Ynet reported early assessments suggested the captives might have succumbed to carbon dioxide inhalation, following IDF strikes on a nearby Hamas target. During a media session on Tuesday, IDF spokesperson Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari declined to confirm whether the captives were killed due to Israeli military actions. Instead, he referred to a statement he made in June, stating the hostages perished while IDF forces were operating in Khan Younis. The unfortunate incidents reinstated calls for a ceasefire among protesters in Tel Aviv on Thursday. Omer, 46, attending the protest with his two daughters, believed they "could have been rescued much sooner." He accused the Israeli government of delaying the agreement with Hamas, which, he warned, would lead to a more expensive agreement that could have been secured earlier. A ceasefire would also relieve tens of thousands of Palestinians in the blockaded enclave as Israel presses on with its military campaign. United Nations estimated in July that approximately 1.9 million people in the strip had been displaced, which almost equaled the total population of Gaza. However, doubts surround Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's intention to reach a deal due to fierce opposition from right-wing ministers within his coalition. Netanyahu's political fate hinges on his right-wing coalition partners, with some already threatening to abandon the government if he agrees to the deal, potentially leading to its collapse. "Maybe Hamas captured them (the hostages), but the one we can blame for their murder is Benjamin Netanyahu," Omer claimed, adding that the prime minister is "solely responsible." A group representing the families of Israeli hostages, the Hostages and Missing Families Forum, criticized Israeli authorities in a statement on Thursday, asserting that the forensic test results suggesting gunshot wounds were "further evidence of the cruelty of the terrorists" who kept them captive. The Forum also reiterated its criticism of Israeli authorities, stating that the recovery of bodies was "no achievement." "It is a testament to the complete failure to strike a deal in time, as six hostages who were expected to return alive instead returned in coffins," the Forum said. Israeli officials identified the recovered bodies as belonging to Yoram Metzger, Alexander Dancyg, Avraham Munder, Chaim Peri, Nadav Popplewell, and Yagev Buchshtab on Tuesday. Except for Munder, all the deceased had been previously declared dead by the Israeli military. Israel's Defense Minister Yoav Gallant stated that IDF and ISA had entered Hamas tunnels in a "complicated operation" to retrieve their remains. Munder was taken captive along with his wife, daughter, and grandson, who were later released during a temporary truce between Israel and Hamas in November. Munder's son, Roee, was killed during the attack. Nine-year-old Ohad Munder conveyed his feelings to Israel's public broadcast channel Kan 11, stating that the demise of his grandfather and the other captives "shouldn't have happened." "There have been numerous opportunities for a deal... but then they say no, only to regret it at the last moment. All the hostages could have returned alive from the start. They could have brought back my grandfather and all the other hostages," Ohad said. Currently, there are 109 Israeli captives still in Gaza, including 36 thought to be deceased, according to data from the Israeli Government Press Office. The world has expressed sympathy and concern over the tragic loss of the captives, with many calling for a peaceful resolution in the Middle East. Despite the conflicting reports about the cause of death, the discovery of gunshot wounds on some bodies has raised concerns about the role of Hamas militants and the Israeli military in this unfortunate incident.

author: TO Acorn Staff
title: Chemical accident results in shelter-in-place orders for three-block T.O. neighborhood
text:
Chemical accident results in shelter-in-place orders for three-block T.O. neighborhood By TO Acorn Staff on February 21, 2025
HAZMAT—First responders, including the Ventura County Fire Department’s hazardous materials units, responded Feb. 12 to a chemical accident in Thousand Oaks. Courtesy Ventura County Fire Department
Residents in a Thousand Oaks neighborhood were asked to shelter in place last week as authorities responded to a hazardous materials incident the Ventura County Sheriff’s Office is describing as an accident involving readily available chemicals.
At around 5:15 p.m. Feb. 12, Ventura County firefighters responded to the area of Calle Avallano and Calle Olivo to help a person injured in a chemical reaction. By the time they arrived, the minor involved had already been taken to Los Robles Regional Medical Center, said Ventura County Fire Department public information officer Andrew Dowd.
Because the responding units had not yet determined the nature of the chemicals involved, the department sent a hazardous materials unit to the hospital and issued a shelter-in-place order for a three-block area of the neighborhood, located just north of Avenida de los Arboles and west of the 23 Freeway.
“We did that as a precaution until we were able to rule out any danger to the community,” Dowd said. “Rescuer safety, public safety and environmental safety are paramount to what we do.”
Once the VCFD team was able to establish the home was safe for Ventura County Sheriff officers to enter, the fire department handed the investigation over, Dowd said.
The sheriff’s office has since determined the mixing of the involved materials— which VCSO said can be purchased online or in a store—was accidental.
The Sheriff’s department is not naming the materials.
— Becca Whitnall
topics: Disaster and Accident->industrial accident and incident

author: Nick Caruso
title: Nick Offerman Shares Full, Flub-Free Emmy Speech Following First Win: ‘This Was the Best Script I’ve Ever Been Handed’
text:
By providing your information, you agree to our
Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google https://policies.google.com/privacy and Terms of Service apply. Nick Offerman is sharing his gratitude with the world after winning his very first Emmy during Saturday’s Creative Arts Emmys ceremony. The actor took home the trophy for Outstanding Guest Actor in a Drama Series for his role in HBO’s The Last of Us, and since emotions were “running high” during his speech, he posted it in full on social media Sunday.
“Well, friends, I won an Emmy art trophy last night for my guest star role [in] HBO’s gorgeous rendition of a Craig Mazin script,” the actor captioned on
After thanking the Academy for the “pat on the back,” the actor quickly acknowledged his scene partner, Murray Bartlett, jokingly referring to him as “the Girth from Perth.” He went on to thank the creative forces at HBO and The Last of Us creator Neil Druckman, among others, before setting his sights on series creator Craig Mazin.
“We would all just be standing around with our thumbs up our asses if Craig Mazin had not written this script,” he said during his acceptance. “This was the best script I’ve ever been handed. If you enjoy what we do, then it’s always and only because the writing is so good, and I’m so grateful to be able to participate in this tradition of ‘storytelling as medicine,’ with which we demonstrate our devotion to each other, because as Wendell Berry says, it all turns on affection.”
Offerman also made sure to drop in a reference to his character’s love for strawberries. Read the actor’s full acceptance speech below.
Night 1 of the Creative Arts
Emmys were held Saturday, with The Last of Us dominating with eight wins total. It took home trophies for Guest Actor and Actress (Storm Reid), main title design, prosthetic makeup, single-camera picture editing, sound editing, sound mixing and visual effects. ( Click here for a list of the winners thus far.)
The Creative Arts Emmys will continue Sunday night with awards for Outstanding Unstructured Reality Program, Structured Reality Program, and Documentary or Nonfiction Series, among others. An edited presentation will be broadcast on Saturday, Jan. 13 at 8/7c on FXX, while the main Emmys ceremony,
hosted by Anthony Anderson, airs Monday, Jan. 15 at 8/7c on Fox.
